Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208 (statutory provi.raw_text: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208 (statutory provisions governing custody and modification of custody orders)
Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208 (statutory provi.proposition: The Probate and Family Court has authority to modify custody and visitation orders when there has been a material change in circumstances and modification is in the best interests of the child.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 209C (parentage and.proposition: The Probate and Family Court has authority to modify custody and visitation orders when there has been a material change in circumstances and modification is in the best interests of the child.

Uniform Child Custody Jurisdiction and E.raw_text: Uniform Child Custody Jurisdiction and Enforcement Act (UCCJEA), codified in Massachusetts (jurisdictional matters).
Uniform Child Custody Jurisdiction and E.proposition: The Probate and Family Court has authority to modify custody and visitation orders when there has been a material change in circumstances and modification is in the best interests of the child.

Custody of a Minor, 439 Mass. 600 (2003).raw_text: Custody of a Minor, 439 Mass. 600 (2003) (standard for modification)
Custody of a Minor, 439 Mass. 600 (2003).proposition: The established Massachusetts standard requires a showing of a material change in circumstances since the entry of the prior order and that the proposed modification is in the child’s best interests.
Custody of a Minor, 439 Mass. 600 (2003).case_name: Loyal Order of Moose, Inc., Yarmouth Lodge 2270 v. Board of Health
Custody of a Minor, 439 Mass. 600 (2003).support_reasoning: The provided opinion is not Custody of a Minor, 439 Mass. 600 (2003), but instead a case involving a lodge challenging municipal smoking and outdoor cooking regulations, focusing on preliminary injunction standards and board of health authority. It does not address modification of custody orders, material change in circumstances, or best interests of the child. Therefore it cannot support the claimed proposition about the Massachusetts standard for modification of custody orders.
Custody of a Minor, 439 Mass. 600 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “In deciding whether the lodge met its burden to obtain a preliminary injunction, the judge properly considered the familiar standards set forth in Packaging Indus. Group, Inc. v. Cheney, 380 Mass. 609 (1980), and Commonwealth v. Mass. CRINC, 392 Mass. 79 (1984). ‘[W]e must look to the same factors properly considered by the judge in the first instance.’ Packaging Indus. Group, Inc. v. Cheney, supra at 615-616.”

Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000).raw_text: Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000) (parental rights and best interests principles)
Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000).proposition: Courts have recognized that parental substance abuse and demonstrated impairment that places a child at risk constitute a material change in circumstances justifying modification of custody or visitation, including the imposition of supervised visitation or suspension of overnight visits.
Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000).support_reasoning: Troxel v. Granville is a U.S. Supreme Court case about the constitutional due process rights of fit parents to control third‑party (grandparent) visitation. It does not address parental substance abuse, impairment, or material change in circumstances, nor does it discuss modification of custody/visitation based on such factors or the imposition of supervised or restricted visitation for that reason. The case instead focuses on the breadth and constitutionality of a nonparental visitation statute and the deference owed to fit parents’ decisions, so it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “First, the Troxels did not allege, and no court has found, that Granville was an unfit parent. That aspect of the case is important, for there is a presumption that fit parents act in the best interests of their children. … Accordingly, so long as a parent adequately cares for his or her children (i.e., is fit), there will normally be no reason for the State to inject itself into the private realm of the family….”
